intro: Galium guadalupense, commonly known as the Guadalupe bedstraw, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its prostrate or ascending growth habit. The plant features small, white to pale pink flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate to elliptic, and covered in fine hairs. Galium guadalupense is often found in rocky soils and open woodlands, thriving in partial shade to full sun.
